匈牙利政府周五向其公民发出了一项调查，询问欧盟是否应该向乌克兰分配更多资金或授予其成员国资格，分析人士称此举是总理维克托·欧尔班试图增加支持。

自由派智囊团Republikon 10月份的一项调查显示，欧尔班领导的执政党青民盟的支持率在过去一年下降了5个百分点，而匈牙利正与欧盟最高的通货膨胀率和经济放缓作斗争。

青民盟仍获得 29% 选民的支持，远远领先于最接近的反对派竞争对手 12%，但欧尔班将热衷于在明年 6 月欧洲议会选举之前扭转颓势。

公平政治分析中心智囊团的政治分析师佐尔坦·诺瓦克表示：“脱离选民基础的情况已经开始……这场竞选活动旨在阻止这种情况发生。” “这是动摇核心选民的好工具。”

民意调查机构 Median 的另一项调查也显示，2 月至 10 月期间，青民盟的支持率下降了 5 个百分点。

欧尔班自2010年上台以来，一直与欧盟就欧盟冻结匈牙利获得数十亿欧元资金的问题发生争执，原因是担心匈牙利在其统治期间民主倒退，欧尔班否认了这些指控。

调查中的问题将欧盟描述为支持乌克兰而不是其成员国之一的匈牙利。

本周早些时候，欧尔班表示，欧盟向乌克兰提供资金和军事援助的战略失败了，他反对与基辅启动入盟谈判。

他的政府对乌克兰采取了与欧盟其他国家不同的立场，不提供武器并批评欧盟对俄罗斯的制裁，尽管它最终支持了迄今为止的所有制裁。

Boldizsar Gyori 报道 Mark Potter 编辑; Fri, 17 Nov 2023 11:29:55 GMT B7BFJYUWDVONTD6N4ZANP4P7VE https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/hungarys-orban-seeks-stir-support-with-survey-questioning-eu-policies-ukraine-2023-11-17/Reuters匈牙利政府/乌克兰欧盟 (PIX) Biden, Trump unpopularity buoys third party hopes for 2024 US election

在 2024 年总统竞选中，面对共和党人唐纳德·特朗普或民主党人乔·拜登之间可能的选择，许多美国人迫切需要更年轻、分歧较小的选择。

第三方候选人的巨大且可能产生重大影响的市场——自 20 世纪 90 年代以来从未出现过——清楚地提醒人们，特朗普和拜登这两个主要政党可能会提名异常不受欢迎的候选人。

他们可能在 2020 年大选中重演之际，正值美国面临经济焦虑、尖锐的政治分歧、 美国支持的以色列对加沙的有争议的袭击以及对新一代美国领导层的广泛呼声等问题。

盖洛普最近的一项民意调查显示，目前约有 63% 的美国成年人同意这样的说法，即共和党和民主党在代表美国人民方面“做得很差”，“需要第三个主要政党”。比一年前增加了 7 个百分点，是盖洛普 2003 年首次提出该问题以来的最高水平。

拜登和特朗普都面临初选挑战者，但预计将在 2024 年成为各自政党的候选人，尽管人们对拜登的年龄以及特朗普的一系列联邦和州刑事起诉深感担忧。

没有第三方候选人赢得现代美国总统选举，尽管他们有时会通过从主要政党候选人手中夺取选票来扮演破坏者的角色。

1992 年，亿万富翁商人罗斯·佩罗 (Ross Perot) 获得了 19% 的选票，可以说将白宫的宝座让给了民主党人比尔·克林顿 (Bill Clinton)，而不是现任的乔治·H·W·布什 (George HW Bush)。

2000 年，政治活动家拉尔夫·纳德 (Ralph Nader) 获得的支持率还不到 3%，但却从佛罗里达州的民主党候选人阿尔·戈尔 (Al Gore) 手中抢走了足够多的选票，让乔治·W·布什 (George W. Bush) 赢得了该州的胜利，并入主白宫。

现在， 路透社/益普索的一项民意调查显示，反疫苗阴谋论者、民主党王朝的后裔小罗伯特·F·肯尼迪(Robert F. Kennedy Jr.)在与拜登和特朗普的三人竞争中可能获得20%的支持率，他于10月发起了独立总统竞选。

肯尼迪得到了“美国价值观 2024”SuperPac 的支持，该组织已从包括特朗普前支持者在内的几位财力雄厚的捐助者那里为他的竞选筹集了超过 1700 万美元。

周二，“美国价值观 2024”在曼哈顿市中心举办了一场针对黑人和拉丁裔选民的活动，吸引了约 40 人参加，其中包括几名无法识别肯尼迪核心政策的人，但表示他们重视他的颠覆性潜力。

“自巴拉克·奥巴马以来，我们一直在寻找叛逆者。我们认为他是叛逆者，然后我们认为伯尼·桑德斯是叛逆者。然后我们认为特朗普是叛逆者。现在，我们当然知道，罗伯特·肯尼迪是叛逆者， ”参加此次活动的前纽约州州长自由党候选人拉里·夏普说道。

双方都对肯尼迪的竞选表示担忧。民主党人担心他著名的姓氏和支持环境、反企业的政策会引起一些选民的共鸣。共和党人担心他的反疫苗言论和在保守派平台上的受欢迎程度可能会吸引他们的一些支持。

路透社/益普索民意调查和其他民意调查显示，肯尼迪在共和党和民主党三人竞选中的支持率相当平分。然而，民主党人并不认为任何事情都是理所当然的。

联合创始人马特·贝内特 (Matt Bennett) 表示：“我们的总体看法是，任何分裂反特朗普联盟的行为都是不好的。因此，除了乔·拜登之外，你为那些根本无法投票给特朗普的选民提供的任何选择都是有问题的。”中左翼民主党团体“第三条道路”的成员。

美国价值观 2024 联合创始人托尼·莱昂斯 (Tony Lyons) 告诉路透社，肯尼迪不应被视为仅对拜登或特朗普构成威胁。莱昂斯在曼哈顿活动中表示：“他对腐败的两党制度构成了威胁，该制度没有采取任何行动来帮助在座的人们。”

特朗普竞选发言人史蒂文·张(Steven Cheung)表示：“民意调查显示，即使有其他候选人在场，无论是在全国还是在战场州，特朗普总统绝对压倒乔·拜登。”

拜登竞选团队拒绝发表评论，将第三方的批评留给了“第三条道路”等外部团体，担心外部竞标可能会将选举拱手让给特朗普。

“人们想要更好的选择”

虽然现金流向第三方选项，但拜登和特朗普筹集的资金更多。总统及其盟友上一季度筹集了 7100 万美元，特朗普筹集了 4550 万美元。

第三方政治团体 No Labels 已为 2024 年筹集了 6000 万美元，并获得了参加 11 个州投票的资格，其中包括亚利桑那州、内华达州和北卡罗来纳州等战场州，但尚未确定候选人。

“过去两年来，我们一直在努力了解选民的脉搏，但结果一直在讲述同一个故事，那就是人们想要更好的选择，”无标签组织的首席策略师瑞安·克兰西说。在为国会温和派提供支持几年后参加总统竞选。

该组织一直在向马里兰州前共和党州长拉里·霍根和来自西弗吉尼亚州的保守派民主党参议员乔·曼钦示好，后者最近宣布不会寻求连任参议院议员。

当被问及是否正在考虑入主白宫时，曼钦周三告诉 NBC 新闻：“我将尽我所能来帮助我的国家。”

克兰西表示，No Labels 计划在 4 月份举行提名大会，如果拜登与特朗普的复赛似乎不可避免并且相信其候选人能够获胜，他们将选出总统候选人。

其他第三方候选人被视为威胁较小。康奈尔·韦斯特 (Cornel West) 是一位哲学家和黑人社会领袖，他也以独立人士身份参选，并希望他直面进步的政治风格能够影响 2024 年的辩论。

吉尔·斯坦最近宣布，她将作为绿党候选人再次竞选白宫。预计韦斯特和斯坦因都将获得微不足道的选票，并且很难进入州选票。

在最近接受 ProPublica 采访时，拜登被问及他的前民主党同事乔·利伯曼 (Joe Lieberman) 在“无标签”组织中寻找和支持温和派第三方候选人的工作。拜登指出，利伯曼拥有这样做的民主权利，但他补充道：“现在，这将帮助另一个人，他知道这一点。”

贾勒特·伦肖报道；希瑟·蒂蒙斯和迪帕·巴宾顿编辑; Fri, 17 Nov 2023 11:27:09 GMT POIAF3TX4BNR7EDR2D6YYICV6Q https://www.reuters.com/world/us/biden-trump-unpopularity-buoys-third-party-hopes-2024-us-election-2023-11-17/Jarrett Renshaw美国选举/第三方 (PIX) East Ukraine's Kharkiv builds underground schools as Russia keeps up attacks

面对俄罗斯空袭的持续威胁，乌克兰东部哈尔科夫地区的官员已经开始建造戒备森严的地下学校，以便孩子们能够在莫斯科的入侵持续进行时安全地重返课堂学习。

2022 年 2 月俄罗斯入侵后，该地区距离俄罗斯边境仅 20 英里（32 公里）、约有 250 万人的学校被迫进行在线学习。

哈尔科夫市经常成为俄罗斯导弹、无人机和大炮的攻击目标，州长周四报告称，过去 24 小时内，三个不同地区的定居点遭到袭击。

首席地区建筑师安东·科罗特科夫斯基赫 (Anton Korotkovskykh) 表示，目前正在建设两所学校，每所可容纳 500 人，将能够承受直接袭击。

“这些结构将配备学习过程所需的一切，”他在接受路透社采访时表示。

科罗特科夫斯基说，计划在明年年底前进行更多的建设，并补充说，哈尔科夫地区的 817 个教育设施在俄罗斯入侵期间遭到损坏或毁坏。

最近的一个早晨，工人们将多层钢筋焊接在一起并浇筑水泥，偶尔会响起定期响起的空袭警报声。

正在建造其中一所学校的建筑公司 Serhiy Petrulyanis 表示，这些空间将配备功能齐全的通风、管道和供暖系统。

“也就是说，人们将能够在这里停留超过一天，”他说。

乌克兰人现在正准备迎接另一个冬天，俄罗斯可能会对关键基础设施发动空袭，去年的空袭导致全国大范围停电。

维塔利·赫尼迪 (Vitalii Hnidyi) 报道；作者：Dan Peleschuk 编辑：Gareth Jones ; Fri, 17 Nov 2023 11:25:18 GMT GWIQ7PDWARPXNDXQOSYLHHAOWU https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/east-ukraines-kharkiv-builds-underground-schools-Russia-keeps-up-attacks-2023-11-17/Vitalii Hnidyii乌克兰危机/地下学校（电视、PIX） Ukraine says 151 ships have used Black Sea corridor

乌克兰国际文传电讯社周五援引一位政府高级官员的话说，自乌克兰新的黑海航运走廊于 8 月建立以来，已有约 151 艘船只使用该走廊。

改造和基础设施部副部长尤里·瓦斯科夫 (Yuriy Vaskov) 表示，共有 440 万吨货物通过该走廊运输，其中包括 320 万吨谷物。

俄罗斯退出后，联合国支持的一项允许乌克兰通过黑海出口粮食安全通行的协议于 7 月破裂。

作为回应，乌克兰宣布在罗马尼亚和保加利亚附近的黑海西海岸建立一条“人道主义走廊”。

瓦斯科夫表示，目前有30艘船正在乌克兰港口装货。其中包括22艘装载70万吨粮食的船只和8艘准备装载50万吨其他货物的船只。

乌克兰是世界主要粮食生产国和出口国之一。保持粮食出口畅通对其经济至关重要，去年该国经济萎缩了约三分之一。预计今年增长5%左右。

奥琳娜·哈马什报道；杰森·尼利编辑; Fri, 17 Nov 2023 11:24:55 GMT 6BBGHESTZNPQRPU4BAMO4VWQKU https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukraine-says-151-ships-have-used-black-sea-corridor-2023-11-17/Reuters乌克兰危机/走廊（更新 1） Argentina on a knife-edge as presidential election offers clashing visions of the future

阿根廷选民既愤怒又害怕。哪一个更强大将打破这个南美国家周日总统选举的平衡，并可能重塑其外交关系、经济未来以及更广泛地区的政治断层线。

这个拥有约 4500 万人口的国家将在 11 月 19 日的第二轮选举中投票，投票者是执政党庇隆派现任经济部长塞尔吉奥·马萨(Sergio Massa) 和自由主义局外人哈维尔·米雷 (Javier Milei )。民意调查显示，竞选激烈，选民分歧严重。

布宜诺斯艾利斯及其他地区的民众对政府感到愤怒，政府导致通货膨胀率飙升至 150% ，导致五分之二的人口陷入贫困。这削弱了马萨的力量，并推动了他的右翼竞争对手的突然崛起。

与此相反的是对米雷的恐惧，他是一位头发蓬乱的前电视评论员，其直言不讳和咄咄逼人的风格让一些人将他与美国前总统唐纳德·特朗普进行比较。他经常出现在集会上挥舞着电锯，这是他削减国家支出计划的象征。

两位候选人对该国的未来提出了截然不同的愿景，该国是大豆、玉米、牛肉和锂的重要出口国， 是国际货币基金组织（IMF）全球最大的债务国，也是不断崛起的页岩油和天然气生产国。

米雷严厉批评中国和其他左翼政府，他宽松地称其为“共产主义”，包括巴西的左翼政府。他希望将阿根廷陷入困境的经济美元化并关闭央行；他反对堕胎。

马萨是左翼政府中的中间派，他将自己描绘成福利国家和南方共同市场区域贸易集团的捍卫者，但他却因未能稳定经济而背负着枷锁。

“我倾向于米莱，”布宜诺斯艾利斯 79 岁的退休人员拉克尔·潘帕 (Raquel Pampa) 说，她补充说，她对主流政客的腐败行为感到厌倦。

“钱不会投入公共工程，也不会为退休人员或收入微薄的工人提供食物——它会增加政客的腰包。”

然而，马萨通过批评米莱的“电锯”经济计划赢得了一些选民的支持，他说该计划可能会影响福利发放，并推高目前由国家补贴的交通、 能源费用和医疗保健的价格。

51 岁的媒体行业工作人员费尔南多·佩德内拉 (Fernando Pedernera) 表示：“我投票给塞尔吉奥·马萨，因为目前正在争论的两种模式，而他的模式基本上可以保证我活下去。”他还批评米莱的竞选搭档捍卫阿根廷前军事独裁政权。

巴西、墨西哥和西班牙的左翼总统均表示支持马萨，秘鲁诺贝尔奖获得者作家马里奥·巴尔加斯·略萨以及智利和哥伦比亚的右翼前领导人则支持米莱。

“不是我的第一选择”

马萨和米莱都没有以强有力的授权进入第二轮。马萨在 10 月份的第一轮选举中获得了 37% 的支持率，而米雷则获得了 30%，尽管此后他赢得了一个关键保守派集团的支持，如果转化为选票，这可能会推动他越过底线。

民意调查显示，两人旗鼓相当，一些人支持米莱，另一些人则预测马萨获胜。 全国各地的许多选民都不相信这两者。

31 岁的尼古拉斯·特罗伊蒂诺 (Nicolas Troitino) 在布宜诺斯艾利斯说：“这个周日我已经决定，我不会投票给这两位候选人中的任何一位。”

“对我来说，他们都不代表我对国家未来的希望。他们花更多的时间互相争斗，而不是解决人民的问题。”

米莱是一位两年前才从政的自由主义经济学家，他赢得了铁杆支持，尤其是年轻人的支持，同时也吸引了一些希望因经济危机而惩罚庇隆主义者的中间立场选民。

“我会把票投给米莱，这不是我的第一选择，但这是我留下的选择，”21 岁的学生瓦伦蒂娜 (Valentina) 说，她拒绝透露自己的姓氏。

“我不同意他所有的社会政策，但我确实同意他的大部分经济计划。在我看来，马萨并没有提出一个计划，他没有说他要做什么。”

马萨去年被任命为“超级部长”，试图扭转经济局面，但迄今为止一直难以控制经济，通货膨胀加速达到30年来的最高水平。净外汇储备严重亏损。

然而，与米雷不同的是，他确实拥有丰富的政治经验，并且被视为能够跨越政治分歧以及与该国强大的工会、公司和投资者进行谈判的人。

31 岁的司法工作人员贡萨洛 (Gonzalo) 表示：“在我看来，展望未来，他是唯一真正得到整个政治舞台支持的政治演员，无论是反对党还是执政党。”姓名。

“我不知道他是否是最好的，但在这种情况下，在这种正面交锋的情况下，在我看来，他是这个国家最可行的选择。”

新国会已在十月的第一轮投票中决定，将高度分散，没有一个集团拥有多数席位，这意味着无论谁获胜都需要得到其他派系的支持才能推动立法。

随着战争即将进入第七周，尽管国际社会呼吁停火或至少人道主义暂停，但没有任何缓和的迹象。

这场冲突是由哈马斯武装分子 10 月 7 日的跨境袭击引发的，袭击造成约 1,200 名以色列人死亡，其中大部分是平民，这是该国 75 年历史上死亡人数最多的一天。

Reporting by Essi Lehto and Anne Kauranen, editing by Terje Solsvik ; Fri, 17 Nov 2023 10:52:07 GMT H6X5VPDF6FLARJB27LCFIZF2WE https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/finland-place-barriers-finnish-russian-border-midnight-2023-11-17/Reuters FINLAND RUSSIA/BORDER (UPDATE 1) Insight: Without a post-war plan, Israel risks a bloody insurgency in GazaSummary:
  • With no exit strategy, Israel risks long engagement in Gaza
  • Israel invasion to generate more Hamas fighters, sources say
  • Israel may face Iraq, Afghanistan insurgency playbook
  • US, allies want "revitalized" Palestinian Authority to run Gaza

Israel risks facing a long and bloody insurgency if it defeats Hamas and occupies Gaza without a credible post-war plan to withdraw its troops and move toward the creation of a Palestinian state, US and Arab officials, diplomats and analysts said.

None of the ideas floated so far by Israel, the United States and Arab nations for the post-war administration of Gaza have managed to gain traction, according to two US and four regional officials as well as four diplomats familiar with the discussions, raising fears the Israeli military may become mired in a prolonged security operation.

As Israel tightens its control over northern Gaza, some officials in Washington and Arab capitals fear it is ignoring lessons from the US invasions of Iraq and Afghanistan when swift military victories were followed by years of violent militancy.

If Gaza's Hamas-run government is toppled, its infrastructure destroyed and its economy ruined, the radicalization of an enraged population could fuel an uprising targeting Israeli troops in the enclave's narrow streets, diplomats and officials say.

Israel, the US and many Arab states agree that Hamas should be ousted after it launched a cross-border raid on Oct. 7 that killed some 1,200 people and took around 240 hostages. But there is no consensus on what should replace it.

Arab countries and Western allies have said a revitalized Palestinian Authority (PA) – which partially governs the West Bank – is a natural candidate to play a greater role in Gaza, home to some 2.3 million people.

But the credibility of the Authority – run by 87-year-old President Mahmoud Abbas' Fatah party - has been undermined by its loss of control over Gaza to Hamas in a 2007 conflict, its failure to halt the spread of Israeli settlements in the West Bank, and accusations of widespread corruption and incompetence.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said at the weekend that the PA in its current form should not take charge of Gaza. He said the Israeli military was the only force capable of eliminating Hamas and ensuring that terrorism did not reappear. In the wake of Netanyahu's comments, Israeli officials have insisted that Israel does not intend to occupy the Gaza Strip.

Mohammed Dahlan, who was the PA's security chief for Gaza until it lost control of the strip to Hamas and has been suggested as a future leader of a post-war government there, said that Israel was mistaken if it believed that tightening its control of Gaza would end the conflict.

"Israel is an occupying force and the Palestinian people will deal with it as an occupying force," Dahlan said in his office in Abu Dhabi, where he now lives. "None of the Hamas leadership or fighters will surrender. They will blow themselves up but won't surrender."

Dahlan has the backing of the influential United Arab Emirates to lead a post-war administration in Gaza, according to diplomats and Arab officials. But he said no-one, certainly not him, would want to come in to govern a broken and demolished territory without a clear political path in sight.

"I have not seen any vision from Israel, America or the international community," Dahlan said, calling for Israel to stop the war and to start serious talks on ​​a two-state solution.

US President Joe Biden warned Netanyahu on Wednesday that occupying Gaza would be 'a big mistake'. So far, the US and its allies have not seen any clear roadmap from Israel for its exit strategy from Gaza beyond the declared aim of eradicating Hamas, diplomats say. US officials are pressing Israel for realistic objectives and a plan for how to achieve them.

The Israeli government did not respond to requests for comment on its post-war plan in Gaza. Israel's operation in Gaza – launched in retaliation for the Oct. 7 attack – has so far killed more than 11,000 people and left more than 1 million people homeless, according to the UN and Red Crescent.

While insisting on Israel's right to defend itself, some US officials are concerned that high civilian casualties could radicalize more Palestinians, driving new fighters into the arms of Hamas or future militant groups that might spring up to replace it, according to a source familiar with US policymaking.

More than a dozen Gazans interviewed by Reuters said the Israeli invasion was spawning a new generation of militants. Abu Mohammad, 37, a public servant from Jabalia refugee camp, said he would rather die than face Israeli occupation.

"I am not Hamas but in days of war, we are all one people, and if they finish off the fighters, we will take up the rifles and fight," he told Reuters, declining to give his full name for fear of reprisals. "The Israelis may occupy Gaza, but they will never feel secure, not for a day."

US-LED TALKS

Washington's discussions of a post-war plan for Gaza are still in the very initial stages with the PA, other Palestinian stakeholders, and allies including Egypt, Jordan, UAE, Saudi Arabia and Qatar, according to two US officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity.

"We're certainly not there yet in terms of any effort to sell that vision to our regional partners who ultimately will have to live with it, and or implement it," one senior US official said.

While Biden has insisted the war must end with a "vision" for a two-state solution – which would unify the Gaza Strip and the West Bank into a Palestinian state - he and his senior aides have neither offered specifics on how they expect to achieve this nor proposed a restart of talks.

Some experts see any effort to revive the negotiations as a long shot, not least because of the embittered mood of Israelis over Hamas' Oct. 7 atrocities and of Palestinians due to Israel's retaliation in Gaza.

"Among the many tragedies of Hamas's terrorist attack is that it fundamentally undermined and set back the Palestinian cause for a sovereign, independent state," said Jonathan Panikoff, the US government's former deputy national intelligence officer on the Middle East who is now at the Atlantic Council think tank.

According to a person familiar with the matter, Biden may decide on a more modest initiative that could include outlining a path towards an eventual resumption of negotiations. Biden's aides recognize that Netanyahu and his far-right coalition, which has rejected the notion of Palestinian statehood, has little appetite for renewed talks.

As Biden seeks re-election next year, he may be reluctant to alienate pro-Israel voters by being seen to pressure Netanyahu for concessions to the Palestinians.

US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, in a speech last week in Tokyo, explained Washington's red lines in Gaza, saying the administration was opposed to the forced displacement of Palestinians from the territory, any reduction in its size, its occupation or blockade by Israel. He also said it could not become a platform for terrorism.

Blinken has repeatedly said Washington would like to see a "revitalized" PA ultimately running the Gaza Strip and its governance unified with the West Bank.

Under Abbas – who has run the Authority since 2005 – its credibility has dwindled as the promise of a path to a two-state solution outlined in the 1993 Oslo peace accords has ebbed.

That dynamic needs to shift, US officials say. A change of leadership within the PA might be possible, with Abbas remaining perhaps in an honorary role, some diplomats said. Another step under discussion is handing the PA a key role in distributing post-war aid in Gaza to revive its legitimacy, a senior European diplomat said.

Asked about the discussions, a senior PA official said the return of the Authority to Gaza was the only acceptable scenario and that was being discussed with the US and other Western powers. He declined to comment on the proposal that Dahlan or others could lead a Palestinian government.

Some senior Palestinian officials, including Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh, have said that the Palestinian Authority will not return to power in Gaza on the back of Israeli tanks.

A proposal for a two-year transitional administration of technocrats in Gaza backed by UN and Arab forces has been floated by Western partners and some Middle Eastern states, diplomats said.

But there has been resistance from key Arab governments – including Egypt - to being drawn into what they regard as the Gaza quagmire, the diplomats said.

Regional powers fear that any Arab forces deployed in Gaza might have to use force against Palestinians and no Arab nation wants its military put in that position.

NO AGREEMENT ON LEADERSHIP

While the ageing Abbas is unpopular among many Palestinians, there is no agreement about who might replace him as a future leader.

Dahlan would likely be acceptable to Egypt and Israel but - though he worked closely with the US during his time as Gaza security chief - a US source said that Washington would have some misgivings about him returning to power. He has a long-running enmity with Abbas and the PA's inner circle, as well as with Hamas supporters.

Dahlan led a wave of arrests and crackdowns against senior Hamas leaders in 1996 after a series of suicide bombings against Israel.

A UAE official said Abu Dhabi would support any post-war arrangements agreed by all parties in the conflict and supported by the United Nations to restore stability and achieve a two-state solution.

Marwan Barghouti, a Fatah leader imprisoned by Israel since 2002 for murder, is popular among many Palestinians but seen by some in Washington as impractical as the Israeli government would be loath to release someone they accuse of having "blood on his hands".

A US official said selecting the leader would be complex as regional players each have their own favorites and interests at heart. Ultimately, Washington would cast its lot with any leader who gains support from the Palestinian people and its regional allies, as well as Israel.

"Clearly a rejuvenation of Palestinian leadership is desperately needed, but getting there again is a very tricky thing," said Joost R. Hiltermann, Middle East and North Africa Program Director of the International Crisis Group. He said Arab nations could veto any candidate they disliked and Hamas – which has portrayed itself as the champion of Palestinian independence – would likely win any election.

The stakes are high with the possibility of the conflict spilling over to the Israeli-occupied West Bank, and beyond Israel.

Not since the US invasion of Iraq in 2003 has there been such widespread concern about military action raging across the Middle East, according to Arab officials and diplomats.

Whatever Biden decides to do diplomatically, his aides say he has no interest in the US getting dragged into a direct military role in the conflict, unless America's own security interests are threatened by Iran or its regional proxies.

"There's no plans or intentions to put US military troops on the ground in Gaza, now or in the future," White House national security spokesperson John Kirby told reporters this month.

Madagascar's President Andry Rajoelina took a predictably commanding early lead on Friday in his bid for re-election in a vote marked by low turnout and an opposition boycott, preliminary results showed.

The 49-year-old entrepreneur and former DJ rose to power on the Indian Ocean island in a 2009 coup, stepped down after almost five years as leader of a transitional authority, then won a 2018 election.

The opposition says he should not have run again in Thursday's poll because he acquired French nationality in 2014 - which they say automatically revokes his Malagasy one - and has created unfair election conditions.

He says both accusations are baseless political tactics.

In preliminary results from the electoral commission CENI, Rajoelina had garnered more than 72.9% of the estimated total of 6.2% counted so far.

Votes counted so far indicated a turnout of 39.5%, compared to 55% in the equivalent first round of voting in 2018.

'ENTHUSIASM NOT THERE'

There were 11 million people out of a population of roughly 30 million registered to vote in this year's polls, which were preceded by weeks of opposition-led protests.

Of 12 opposition candidates originally, only two took part in the vote. One was Marc Ravalomanana, the former president ousted in 2009, the other Siteny Randrianasoloniaiko.

"Enthusiasm was not there," said Andriamanambe Raoto, editor-in-chief of Politika, a monthly publication.

The United States voiced concern on Thursday over low turnout, inadequate training for election staff and irregularities by party officials.

The opposition said participation was the lowest in Madagascar's history and vowed to keep protesting.
